Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Phylogenomics and evolutionary history of the anaerobic fungal group, Neocallimastigomycota
Award.AbstractNarration:
The anaerobic gut fungi (AGF) differ from all other groups of fungi by having a restricted habitat (the rumen and alimentary tract of herbivores), and by growing in the absence of atmospheric oxygen. They have evolved hundreds of millions of years ago and represent one of the oldest fungal groups. However, the evolutionary history of anaerobic fungi is currently unclear. Specifically, the exact relationship between anaerobic fungi and other fungal groups, as well as the timing and sequence of events that lead to their sequestration into the herbivorous gut remain unclear. Further, it is not exactly known how the retention of anaerobic fungi in the herbivorous gut has affected their genomes and evolution. This project will tackle these questions by sequencing the genomes of a large, diverse collection of anaerobic fungi, and analyzing the data produced using a wide range of computational procedures. The project will engage multiple high school and undergraduate students in research, with special effort to engage minority (especially Native American) students to advance the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines.  

Overall research progress on anaerobic fungi has been slow, and sequencing of AGF genomes has been hampered by their extremely high AT content and the proliferation of intergenic repeats in their genomes. This project will utilize a new approach that combines multiple sequencing technologies to sequence the genomes and transcriptomes of a large and diverse collection of anaerobic fungal isolates. This research will utilize the data generated to conduct an extensive phylogenomic analysis, aiming to resolve their evolutionary history within the fungal tree of life, correlate the timing of AGF diversification events to the evolution of their herbivorous hosts, resolve the diversification pattern of anaerobic fungal genera, and investigate the impact of the unique habitat and evolutionary trajectory on their genomic architecture. The proposed efforts will lead to significant advances in the understanding of the history of this peculiar group of fungi and factors driving their evolution. Further, the genomic and transcriptomic data obtained would be of extreme interest to a broader group of scientists working in the areas of biofuel research, animal nutrition, and molecular biology of fungi.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project improved the resolution of evolutionary relationships among a group of fungi, called Neocallimastigomycota, which inhabit the rumen of ruminate animals like cows and sheep. These fungi, which are also called Anaerobic Gut Fungi (AGF), play an important role in assisting the digestion of grasses in the rumen of their host. The efforts produced a more fully resolved understanding of the timing of the emergence of these fungi which are now estimated to be around 66 Million years old. This project generated public datasets of transcriptomes from 21 AGF isolates. The transcriptomes were analyzed in combination with genomes from 5 other AGF species to produce a phylogenetic tree representing the species relationships. This phylogeny was linked to geological time using fossil calibrated divergence of other fungi. The analyses revealed similar divergence times for the Anaerobic Gut Fungi, emergence of grasses consumed by ruminate animals, and the timing of when mammals transitioned from primarily insect food sources to a diet that relied on plants as food sources herbivory.  Our work found all of these transitions occurred within a 60-80 Mya time period.

A second focus of our analyses examined the protein coding gene content with the AGF and identified and manually confirmed at least 280 examples of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) from bacteria, plant, and animal lineages. A majority of the Bacteria HGT could be traced to donors in the Firmicutes and Bacteroidetes phyla and are predicted increase the diversity of enzymes for digesting plant material and expanding the fermentation capabilities of the fungi. One HGT candidate, a Gal Lectin, can be traced to an animal donor include a domain containing protein which may be important for adherence. Another HGT is classified as a Rhamnogal lyase, homologs of this enzyme degrade pectin sugars found in plant cell walls and degradation of these linkages can soften the plant material for digestion. The HGT findings confirm initial observations from the analysis of the first AGF genomes, these fungi have experienced a high level of HGT in contrast to most other fungal lineages. We and others interpret this to be a result of the ecological niche these fungi inhabit in close competition and perhaps cooperation among the consortia of microbes in the rumen.

Overall the findings in this project provided a more accurate representation of the evolutionary relationships and timing of the emergence of this important animal-associated fungal lineage. It further produced new transcriptome and gene resources for these fungi to enable future phylogenetic, comparative, and synthetic biology studies of these organisms.
